Photo-assisted ethanol dry reforming (EDR) for syngas production was deeply studied over nanorod-like Ni/ZrO2 catalyst synthesized by precipitation and impregnation technique, respectively. The effect of light irradiation as well as catalyst preparation method on EDR reaction was investigated in detail with the stoichiometric feed ratios, over a temperature region of 350 to 550 °C. Photo-enhancement factor of ethanol conversion greatly increased from 10% (dark) to 40% (light) together with less formation of byproducts. Moreover, the experimental results depicted the better performance of P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst due to its abundant oxygen vacancies and strong Ni-Zr interaction. Enriched interfacial oxygen defects and more light-excited electrons facilitated the activation/dissociation of ethanol and CO2, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity. In addition, the mean particle size of NiO in P-Ni/ZrO2 was (10.3 nm) which was smaller than that of the I-Ni/ZrO2 (16.5 nm), suggesting its higher dispersion of active metal. The calculated apparent activation energy of P-Ni/ZrO2 was 20.6 eV which was much less than the value of I-Ni/ZrO2 (37.7 eV). This work might provide the valuable insight for the development of highly-efficient photothermal catalyst to enhance the value-added utilization of greenhouse gas CO2. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Photothermal catalyst Dry reforming of ethanol Ni/ZrO2 Syngas Carbon dioxide Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Up to date, chemical conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2), one of the main greenhouse gases, has achieved great attention in order to eliminate the detrimental impact of global warming and climate change [1,2]. In this regard, thermal catalytic CO2 reforming with renewable bio-ethanol (EDR) is a sustainable approach compared to the common methane dry reforming [3-5]. The reactant ethanol can be easily obtained from the abundant biomass resources and the generated syngas (a mixture of CO and H2) is the suitable feedstock for the down-stream Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. (1) C 2 H 5 OH ( g ) + C O 2 ( g ) → 3 CO ( g ) + 3 H 2 ( g ) Δ H 298 K θ = 296.7 kJ / mol In contrast, certain challenges still need to be resolved before EDR process can be widely applied in an industrial scale. As depicted in Eq (1), EDR is generally operated at high temperature because of its endothermic character which leads to high energy consumption and high-cost [6]. Moreover, the utilization of thermal energy derived from conventional fossil fuels might further reduce the efficiency of the EDR reaction [7]. In this regard, photothermal catalysis has been of great interest where solar energy is utilized to compensate thermal energy [8,9]. In the process of photocatalysis, light irradiation could lead to electron excitation and the generation of holes where various reduction and oxidation reactions occur [10-14]. It is accepted that photothermal catalysis combines the synergistic effect of thermal activation and light promotion. Hence, photothermal catalysis is also defined as photodriven thermal process in which solar energy can not only generate heat energy but form electron/hole pairs. Particularly, photothermal condition is more efficient in energy than the conventional thermal heating [15,16]. In addition, a system that accelerates chemical reactions through photothermal heating and generation of photothermal electrons could result in a higher reaction rate and milder conditions than the traditional thermal system [17]. Many studies have depicted that the surface temperature of metal nanoparticles increases significantly upon light irradiation, thereby facilitating photothermal CO2 hydrogenation and dry reforming of methane reaction [18-21]. Huang et al. [22] elucidated that the reaction rate of methane dry reforming over Ag/AgBr/CsPbBr3 catalyst through photo-thermal catalysis was 79 times higher than the value by pure thermal catalysis. Meanwhile, Jia et al. [23] reported that light irradiation could facilitate the formation of hot electrons and oxygen defects which enhanced the activation/dissociation of CO2 and methane. Therefore, photothermal catalytic EDR reaction might be a promising alternative to the conventional thermal EDR considering its sustainability and the relatively low reaction temperature. To the best of our knowledge, EDR reaction promoted by photothermal catalysis has still not been widely investigated. On the other hand, development of low-cost and efficient catalysts is critical to accelerate EDR process in a pilot-scale application. In recent years, Ni-based catalysts have exhibited great potential in dry reforming reaction because of their low price and high activity [24,25]. The performances of Ni-based catalysts not only rely on the dispersion of active Ni nanoparticles but on the physicochemical properties of support. Generally, support can greatly affect the surface catalysis via electronic interaction between active sites and support [26]. In recent years, ZrO2 has been widely used as a support considering its thermal stability, oxygen mobility and high ionic conductivity [27,28]. Moreover, ZrO2 oxide as a support exhibits good performance in photothermal catalysis [29]. In the present work, Ni nanoparticles supported on ZrO2 nanorods (Ni/ZrO2) was constructed to achieve strong Ni-Zr interaction as an efficient photothermal catalyst for the EDR reaction. To optimize the loading of Ni species, two Ni/ZrO2 catalysts were prepared via the precipitation and impregnation method, respectively. The physicochemical features of the as-prepared catalysts were studied by a series of characterization techniques including spectroscopic tools. Photothermal and pure thermal EDR performances were compared to demonstrate the promotion function by the cooperative effect of photo and thermal for syngas production. Actually, the photothermal catalysis exhibited better EDR activity than that of pure thermal catalysis. The comparison of two Ni/ZrO2 catalysts was also carried out in terms of ethanol conversion, syngas production as well as stability. This work might offer new insights into the design of highly efficient photothermal catalysts for light-assisted EDR reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials ZrOCl2⋅8H2O (99%), Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (99%) and ethyl alcohol were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Co. Ltd. NaOH (96%), NH3⋅H2O (25%), CH3OH (99%), Na2CO3 (99%) were obtained from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. The chemicals were of analytical grade and directly used without further pretreatment. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Ni/ZrO2 catalysts were prepared as shown in Scheme I . The detailed information was illustrated in Supplementary Material. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The crystalline properties were analyzed by a D/MAX-2500X-ray diffractometer (XRD) with Cu (Kα) radiation and a scanning range of 20–70° The morphology structure was determined by SEM and TEM techniques. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was selected to depict the surface chemical properties. The pore size distribution and specific surface area were calculated from nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms. CO2-TPD, O2-TPD, H2-TPD and H2-TPR were carried out on a ZHD-TPX-6 apparatus equipped with a TCD. 2.4 Catalytic reactions The experimental conditions were depicted in detail in Supplementary Material. 3 Results and discussion The crystalline and phase structures of the samples were analyzed by XRD profiles, as shown in Fig. 1 a. It could be seen that the bands at 24°, 28.2°, 31.5°, and 34.1 °corresponded to monoclinic ZrO2 (JCPDS #37–1484). [30] On the other hand, the small bands associated with NiO phase (JCPDS#47–1049) were observed in all cases. Based on the spectra obtained, the mean particle sizes (dNiO) were calculated using the Scherrer equation, as listed in Table 1 . Evidently, the particle size of NiO in P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst prepared by precipitation method was (10.3 nm) which was smaller than that of the I-Ni/ZrO2 sample synthesized by impregnation method (16.5 nm). This finding implied the stronger interaction between NiO and ZrO2 support. Similarly, a support anchoring mechanism in Au/CeO2 catalyst was demonstrated by Shen group [31]. It was reported that strong metal-support interaction could greatly enhance the sintering resistance of Ru-based catalysts [32]. Actually, the small particles could facilitate the formation of oxygen defects via reducing its formation enthalpy [33]. As demonstrated by Nabgan et al. [34], small active metal particle size might provide strong resistance to coke accumulation, resulting in excellent catalyst stability. In order to further confirm the crystal structure of the samples, Raman spectroscopy was used as a complementary analysis. As shown in Fig. 1b, several peaks appeared at 177, 190, 221, 302, 346, 382, 475, 558 and 615 cm−1, which corresponded to the characteristic peaks of monoclinic ZrO2 [35]. The Raman peak at 475 cm−1 was assigned to the Eg mode frequency, which was related to the oxygen vacancy of ZrO2. Interestingly, the Egmode frequency of P-Ni/ZrO2 (475 cm−1) was lower than that of I-Ni/ZrO2 (477 cm−1), which could be attributed to a decrease in particle size and an increase in oxygen vacancy [36]. In addition, it was observed that the Raman peaks in P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst were stronger compared to I-Ni/ZrO2, suggesting that the precipitation method might enhance the metal-carrier interaction. This was in line with the previous literature [37]. Based on the above discussion, the precipitation method could result in stronger metal-carrier interaction compared to the impregnation method. As a consequence, both the smaller particles size and the stronger interaction between active metal and support might facilitate CO2 reforming of ethanol. Fig. 1c shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the nanostructured catalysts. In all cases, the isotherms were attributed to type IV curves with a H3 hysteresis loop, indicating the existence of mesoporous structure [38]. As shown in Fig. 1d, P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst presented the smaller pore size distribution in comparison with I-Ni/ZrO2 sample which was in line with the results in Table 1. Meanwhile, the specific surface area of P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst was also higher than that of I-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst. This finding was in well agreement with XRD findings. As depicted by Laguna et al. [39], the smaller particle size corresponded to the larger specific surface area. The previous literatures illustrated that the high surface area could provide more active sites for the adsorption of reactants, thereby improving the catalytic performance [40,41]. TEM images (Fig. 2 a and b) show that ZrO2 displays a nanorod morphology with 50–100 nm in width and 200–300 nm in length. After the loading of Ni species, ZrO2 still maintained the initial nanorod morphology in all cases. However, the smaller Ni nanoparticles were observed over the surface of P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst in comparison with I-Ni/ZrO2. This indirectly implied the stronger metal-support interaction in P-Ni/ZrO2 sample which could efficiently prevent the aggregation of Ni species during the calcinations process. Therefore, the preparation methods might be one of the key factors affecting the dispersion of active metal. H2-TPR profiles were also collected to explore the interaction between NiO and ZrO2. As presented in Fig. 3 a, two obvious reduction peaks were observed for P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst which might be assigned to the reduction of various NiO nanoparticles. Indeed, ZrO2 was difficult to be reduced at below 600 °C. It should be noted that the reduction peaks of P-Ni/ZrO2 were lower than those of I-Ni/ZrO2, suggesting the better low-temperature reducibility of P-Ni/ZrO2 sample. The observed decline of the reduction temperature implied that the interaction between NiO and ZrO2 might enhance the reduction of nickle oxides via the formation of solid solution to improve the oxygen mobility [42]. Interestingly, the P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst was reduced at relatively lower temperature in comparison with I-Ni/ZrO2, thereby implying the stronger metal-support interaction in P-Ni/ZrO2 which was consistent with the previous literature [43]. It was also reported that Ni-based catalysts with smaller particles presented the lower reduction temperature [44]. Hence, the observed difference of reduction temperature was in line with XRD results suggesting the smaller NiO particle size in P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst. This implied that P-Ni/ZrO2 had a higher dispersion which promoted the formation of active sites and facilitated the activation of the reactant molecules. TPR results obviously elucidated that the P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst was favorable to the low-temperature reducibility. H2-TPD profiles of the catalysts are presented in Fig. 3b. It was noted that both catalysts depicted two peaks. Typically, the first peak could be deconvoluted into two peaks. The peak located at lower temperature might be attributed to the weak adsorption of hydrogen on active metal sites while the high temperature one corresponded to the strong hydrogen adsorption [45]. Indeed, the second peak was attributed to hydrogen spillover (metal to metal and/or metal to support) [46,47]. On the other hand, the temperature of H spillover on P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst was obviously lower than that of I-Ni/ZrO2, suggesting the facile hydrogen spillover on P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst. CO2-TPD was selected to determine the catalyst basicity which was important for CO2 adsorption/conversion in dry reforming process [48]. In principle, increasing the basicity could efficiently inhibit the carbon formation via facilitating the oxidation of the coke deposits [49]. As shown in Fig. 3c, all CO2-TPD curves could be deconvoluted into three peaks in the temperature range of 100–500 °C, which corresponded to the weak, moderate and strong basic sites, respectively [50]. Evidently, the peak area of P-Ni/ZrO2 was larger than that of I-Ni/ZrO2, implying more basic sites for P-Ni/ZrO2. Meanwhile, the percentage of moderate and strong basic sites in P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst was higher which was favorable for CO2 adsorption. [51,52] O2-TPD profiles were collected to evaluate the oxygen mobility of the investigated catalysts. As depicted in Fig. 3d, two obvious peaks were observed in which the lower temperature was attributed to the desorption of surface oxygen and another broad one was in indexed with lattice oxygen species [53]. Based on the difference of peak area, the amount of surface oxygen in P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst was higher than the value of I-Ni/ZrO2. Actually, more surface oxygen species might result in better activity. XPS measurements were conducted to further understand the chemical states of the as-prepared catalysts. As presented in Fig. 4 a, the survey spectra consisted of different elements such as Ni, O and Zr, indicating the successful synthesis of Ni/ZrO2 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 4b, the peaks at 184.3 eV and 181.9 eV were associated with Zr 3d3/2 and Zr 3d5/2, respectively [54]. More importantly, the binding energy of Zr for P-Ni/ZrO2 shifted to lower binding energy compared to I-Ni/ZrO2, implying the stronger Ni-Zr interaction in P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst. Meanwhile, two Ni 2p3/2 peaks appeared at ca. 855.6 eV and 852.2 eV (Fig. 4c) which indicated the presence of Ni2+ and Ni0 species [55]. The formation of nickel oxide might be due to the ex-situ operation conditions in XPS tests. On the other hand, the peaks of Ni 2p3/2 for P-Ni/ZrO2 shifted to a higher binding energy compared to I-Ni/ZrO2. This change further evidenced the stronger metal-support interaction in P-Ni/ZrO2. Fig. 4d shows the O1s XPS spectrum. Typically, the peak at 529.3 eV was attributed to the lattice oxygen (Olatt) while the peak at ca.531.4 eV corresponded to the surface oxygen (Osurf) [56]. Indeed, the concentration of Osurf species in P-Ni/ZrO2 (42.8%) was higher than that of I-Ni/ZrO2 (40.3%). It was accepted that surface oxygen (Osurf) such as adsorptive and/or defective species could enhance the catalytic activity [57]. Moreover, more defects might extend the sunlight adsorption capacity of catalyst and improve the photothermal catalytic performance [58]. Wei et al. illustrated that the existence of surface oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface played an important role in promoting the gas-phase oxygen replenishment, thus enhancing the activity [59]. The UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectra were collected to investigate the positive effect of photocatalysis in the thermal-catalytic reaction. As depicted in Fig. 5 , both samples showed obvious light absorption in the ultraviolet region of 200–400 nm, indicating the high ultraviolet absorption capacity, which could be attributed to the presence of ZrO2. The bands might be also a contribution of Ni2+→O2− charge transfer transitions [63]. On the other hand, the absorption strength of P-Ni/ZrO2 in the visible region was stronger than that of I-Ni/ZrO2, implying that P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited better visible light absorption capacity [64-66]. This positive factor could enhance the generation of electron-hole pairs [67]. The band gaps of the catalysts were calculated according to the Kubelka-Munk equation [68,69]. Indeed, the band gap of P-Ni/ZrO2 (4.58 eV) was narrower than the value of I-Ni/ZrO2 (4.82 eV). This result suggested that P-Ni/ZrO2 presented the wider light adsorption range and harvested more solar energy. Moreover, it was smaller in comparison with the previous literature (Table 2 ). Guo et al. elucidated that the decline of band gap was attributed to the existence of oxygen defects [70]. The band gap decrement was favorable for the formation of photoexcited charge carriers, thereby enhancing the photothermal catalytic reactions. In summary, P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst enlarged the optical response region and depicted the higher visible-light capture capacity which resulted in better photothermal catalytic behavior. The ethanol conversion and product selectivity of pure thermal catalysis and photothermal catalysis are shown in Fig. 6 . Obviously, ethanol conversion in photothermal dry reforming (40%) was higher than the value in thermal dry reforming (10%). Meanwhile, less byproducts (methane, acetaldehyde acetone) were generated under the irradiation of light (Fig. 6a). The findings indicated the photothermal synergistic effect. The similar synergism in photothermal catalytic methanol steam reforming was proposed in the previous literature [71]. Moreover, as presented in Fig. 6b, P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited higher ethanol conversion (70%) and more suitable H2/CO ratio (ca.1.1) in photothermal conditions which was desirable for the downstream Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. On the other hand, P-Ni/ZrO2 greatly prevented the formation of byproducts. This result might be a combination contribution of higher dispersion of active metal and abundance in oxygen defects as well as the stronger Ni-Zr interaction in P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst [72]. With a further estimation of temperature influence (Fig. 6c), ethanol conversion evidently increased which was in accordance with the thermodynamics. Besides, hydrogen selectivity in the outlet gas increased while CO selectivity followed the reverse trend. This tendency might be attributed to the occurrence of water gas shift reaction. On the other hand, it could not rule out the contribution of methane decomposition which was confirmed by the continuous decline of methane concentration in the outlet gas. In addition, the apparent activation energy of P-Ni/ZrO2 under photothermal conditions was 20.62 eV which was lower compared to the value in the dark conditions (37.74 eV). This result revealed that the illumination could reduce the activation energy barrier, thereby increasing the reaction rate [73]. The effect of gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) on catalytic performance was investigated over P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst at 450 ℃. As presented in Fig. 7 , increasing GHSV significantly resulted in the decrease of ethanol conversion from 71% to 30%. Meanwhile, the methane selectivity increased from 4 mol% to 26 mol%. The selectivity of acetaldehyde also increased from 2 mol% to 8 mol% and another byproduct acetone increased from 1mol% to 3mol%. The results indicated that the less contact time at higher space velocity caused the decline of reactant conversion while it facilitated the occurrence of side reaction to form more byproducts. Based on the above discussion, the reaction mechanism of photo-induced ethanol dry reforming is proposed, as shown in Fig. 8 . Typically, the excited electrons in ZrO2 were injected into nickel nanoparticles to produce efficient photoelectrons (Fig. 8II). Subsequently, the generated photoelectrons in nickel were trapped by reactant CO2 to form CO and O2− species (Fig. 8III). On the other hand, photo-generated holes in ZrO2 migrated near the interface of the nickel nanoparticles and reacted with ethanol. The residual coke over the catalyst surface might react with O2− species, thereby maintaining the clean surface. 4 Conclusions Photo-assisted ethanol dry reforming reaction over Ni/ZrO2 catalysts were investigated in detail. A deep comprehension of the relationship between the catalytic performance and catalyst properties was depicted via catalyst characterization like TEM, H2-TPR, O2-TPD, CO2-TPD, Raman and UV–Vis technique combined with XPS. Typically, illuminated (light) condition remarkably enhanced the ethanol conversion rate on Ni/ZrO2 catalyst by 4 times. Furthermore, light irradiation retarded the formation rates of byproducts including acetone and methane, suggesting the photothermal synergistic effect. The experimental results indicated that P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst synthesized by precipitation technique exhibited better performance than I-Ni/ZrO2 prepared by impregnation method. The superior activity of P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst was partially ascribed to strong NiO-ZrO2 interaction, which facilitated electron transfer from ZrO2 to Ni and the formation of oxygen defects. Moreover, the better reducibility, light absorption efficiency as well as higher Ni dispersion in P-Ni/ZrO2 could also contribute to its good performance. This insight will provide a critical reference to design highly-efficient catalysts for photothermal EDR systems utilizing solar light. coredata.dc:description: Photo-assisted ethanol dry reforming (EDR) for syngas production was deeply studied over nanorod-like Ni/ZrO2 catalyst synthesized by precipitation and impregnation technique, respectively. The effect of light irradiation as well as catalyst preparation method on EDR reaction was investigated in detail with the stoichiometric feed ratios, over a temperature region of 350 to 550 °C. Photo-enhancement factor of ethanol conversion greatly increased from 10% (dark) to 40% (light) together with less formation of byproducts. Moreover, the experimental results depicted the better performance of P-Ni/ZrO2 catalyst due to its abundant oxygen vacancies and strong Ni-Zr interaction. Enriched interfacial oxygen defects and more light-excited electrons facilitated the activation/dissociation of ethanol and CO2, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity. In addition, the mean particle size of NiO in P-Ni/ZrO2 was (10.3 nm) which was smaller than that of the I-Ni/ZrO2 (16.5 nm), suggesting its higher dispersion of active metal. The calculated apparent activation energy of P-Ni/ZrO2 was 20.6 eV which was much less than the value of I-Ni/ZrO2 (37.7 eV). This work might provide the valuable insight for the development of highly-efficient photothermal catalyst to enhance the value-added utilization of greenhouse gas CO2.
